addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. Wheras I was lately
willed by my
LL.
of
e councell, to solicit
e
Generall states
about
e fortifications of
Ostend,
I have used as muche instance, as I could, in that
behalf. But their answears have bin alwais
very dilatorie. For what respect I can not cer-
tifie yo
r
H. but as farre as I can perceave,
ei
can not agree w
t
those of
Zeland
about disboursing
of
e mony: and w
t
all I see there is great want
of mony on all handes. They doe also say
at the
daunger of
e place is more amplified in wordes,
then there is cause in deede. And whether besides
they have bin moved to attend
e returne of
their Deputies, before any resoluc
o
n be taken,
I can affirme nothing for certaine. But I have
found them very backward, and full of shiftes
and excuses in this cause, pretending
at they
were pressed w
t
other matters of greater impor-
tance, and so putting me of from day to day.
Nevertheles by muche calling uppon them, I have
obtened at length
at they are contented to ap-
point a time to consult, and to take some order
for
e relief of
e towne, wherein they are busied
at this p
nt
: and as any thing is resolved, I
will signifie to my LL.
Count Maurice
is lately gone from North
Holland,
w
t
certain others
of
e Generall states, to accord an old contention
between some of
e greater and
e lesser townes
astouching
e nomber of Deputies, w
ch
eche towne
pretendeth to send to
e college and councell of
those quarters: w
ch
is thought will minister occa-
sion of greater inconvenience, if it be not quieted
in time. We are newly advertised
at
e souldiers of
Liefkens Hoeck
over against
Lillo
are in mutinie: w
ch
is thought to growe about their
pay after 48 daies to
e moneth: for
e present
fol.27v
appeasing, wherof
e Councell of state is very care-
full, lest their example should provoke other garri-
sons to doe
e like. The discontent-
ment of
Schinkes
souldiers, whiche were left in his
fort at
Sgraven Weert
, doth increase more and more,
having made a change among themselves of their
officers. Howbeit there is mony sent of late, and
suche other order taken, as
e state will permitte,
to procure their contentment.
Mons
r
de Haldagne
, whome
e
Frenche King
sent hither to re-
ceave
e mony
at was promised to be lent, is de-
parted from hens in company of those Deputies
at
were appointed for
Fraunce,
having receaved, as
I understand, in ready paiment, somwhat more
then
e half of
at whiche was promised.
The
Count Neuwenar
being lately at
Arnhem,
and
busied about
e direction of certaine artificiall
fires, by
e negligence of one of his pages,
at caried
a light, certaine powder tooke fire, whereby a
great part of
e house was blowen up, one
Cap
t
Denis
an Ingener slaine, and
e Count himself
very daungerously blasted, and brused w
t
e
falle of a walle, so as many men thinke he will
hardly escape it. Theruppon
e charge of victu-
alling
Berke,
wherof I writte in my last to yo
r
H.
was comitted to
e Conduct of
e
Count Oversten
,
S
r
Francis Vere
, and
e
Baron of Potlits
, who as
we are advertised,
e 2 of this moneth in the
open face of
e Enemie conveied into
e towne
24 cartes loaden w
t
Victuall and other neces-
saries, and w
t
in 2 daies after marched thi-
therwardes w
t
more provision:
e successe whereof
is not yet certified hither. From
Grave
and those quarters where
e Enemie lieth
fol.28r
there is a freshe bruite come hither, that
e
D of Parma
is for certaine dead: w
ch
is not
yet otherwise confirmed. The
bearer herof is one
M
r
Yakesley
an Englishe
gentleman, who served sometimes
e E
lecto
r
of
Colen
, and by him was recommended to the
service of
Count Hohenlo
, w
t
whom he hath con-
tinued all
e time of his late absence in
Ger-
many
. He hath bin very well used by
e Count
and is commended by divers for his honest
and discrete demeano
r
. The occasion of his
comming into
England,
yo
r
H. will knowe
by himself and by his l
re
s.
M
r
Diar
is newly heere arrived, and upp
o
his depar-
ture for
Amsterdam.
Wherw
t
I take my
humble leave. From
e Hage. Oct
r
8. 89
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
